pullRequest.body:
Prove special case of Jensen's inequality for binomial coefficients using the descending Pochhammer polynomials.

Also prove

- special case of Jensen's inequality for the descending factorial using the descending Pochhammer polynomials,
- the descending Pochhammer polynomials `descPochhamer · n` are monotone/convex on $$[n-1, \infty)$$,
- misc. analysis/ring theory lemmas for the descending Pochhammer polynomials.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This is needed for a proof of the Kővári–Sós–Turán theorem for simple graphs. See #20240.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
@b-mehta Yaël says you may have some things related to this, especially pertaining to the convexity on pieces of the real line. Maybe there's some code lying around already?

The version I have is a bit different: I defined a function which agrees with descPochhammer on `[n-1, ∞)` but is zero below that, so it's nonnegative, continuous and convex, and did Jensen's inequality on that. I think the approach taken here, which does it for the actual descPochhammer function, is more suitable for mathlib. But I will still poke around and see if any of the auxiliary lemmas are useful.

### PR summary [d6942f7126](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20738/commits/d6942f712657904e172e371a41037c680444f37b)

</details>

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

:v: mitchell-horner can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> @b-mehta Yaël says you may have some things related to this, especially pertaining to the convexity on pieces of the real line. Maybe there's some code lying around already?

The closest thing I found was this (Lean 3; apologies):
```
lemma convex.union {s t : set ℝ} (hs : convex ℝ s) (ht : convex ℝ t)
  (hst : ¬ disjoint s t) : convex ℝ (s ∪ t) :=
begin
  rw set.not_disjoint_iff at hst,
  obtain ⟨a, has, hat⟩ := hst,
  rw [convex_iff_ord_connected, set.ord_connected_iff_uIcc_subset],
  rintro x (hx | hx) y (hy | hy),
  { exact (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hy).trans (set.subset_union_left _ _) },
  { exact set.uIcc_subset_uIcc_union_uIcc.trans (set.union_subset_union
      (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx has) (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hat hy)) },
  { rw set.union_comm,
    exact set.uIcc_subset_uIcc_union_uIcc.trans (set.union_subset_union
      (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hat) (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset has hy)) },
  { exact (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hy).trans (set.subset_union_right _ _) },
end
```
which looks like it could help or generalise your ConvexOn Iic/Ici lemma. 

EDIT: looking again, it's not as useful as I thought; this is convexity of sets rather than of functions on sets

> > @b-mehta Yaël says you may have some things related to this, especially pertaining to the convexity on pieces of the real line. Maybe there's some code lying around already?
> 
> The closest thing I found was this (Lean 3; apologies):
> 
> ```
> lemma convex.union {s t : set ℝ} (hs : convex ℝ s) (ht : convex ℝ t)
>   (hst : ¬ disjoint s t) : convex ℝ (s ∪ t) :=
> begin
>   rw set.not_disjoint_iff at hst,
>   obtain ⟨a, has, hat⟩ := hst,
>   rw [convex_iff_ord_connected, set.ord_connected_iff_uIcc_subset],
>   rintro x (hx | hx) y (hy | hy),
>   { exact (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hy).trans (set.subset_union_left _ _) },
>   { exact set.uIcc_subset_uIcc_union_uIcc.trans (set.union_subset_union
>       (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx has) (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hat hy)) },
>   { rw set.union_comm,
>     exact set.uIcc_subset_uIcc_union_uIcc.trans (set.union_subset_union
>       (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hat) (hs.ord_connected.uIcc_subset has hy)) },
>   { exact (ht.ord_connected.uIcc_subset hx hy).trans (set.subset_union_right _ _) },
> end
> ```
> 
> which looks like it could help or generalise your ConvexOn Iic/Ici lemma.
> 
> EDIT: looking again, it's not as useful as I thought; this is convexity of sets rather than of functions on sets

@b-mehta I get what you are suggesting though, I tried generalizing in this direction but it sort of went nowhere.
bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13768240733/job/38500072462)
Canceled.
Please merge master before borsing again, thanks!
bors r+
I think it's possible to simplify things a little bit.
bors d+
Looks pretty good! Some minor comments below.
I think it's possible to simplify things a little bit.
bors d+
This can go into `Mathlib.RingTheory.Polynomial.Pochhammer` if you generalize to `CommRing`

I'm not sure how I feel about these names. I think it would be more common in mathlib to use `differentiable_descPochhammer_eval` and `continuous_descPochhammer_eval`, but that convention is inherited from lean 3. Maybe this is fine for lean 4.
I have no allegiance to any conventions. I've renamed everything to the convention you suggest.

```suggestion
/-- The function defined to be `0` for `(-∞, n-1)` and `descPochhammer ℝ n` for `[n-1, ∞)` is
convex on the real line. -/
```
or something like that would be clearer, I think.

Throughout: mathlib tends to give more space around operators
```suggestion
    (descPochhammer 𝕜 n).eval k = ∏ j ∈ Finset.range n, (k - j) := by
```

I've added space around `+` and `-` but left some of the white space around `*` in `convexOn_ite_descPochhammer_eval` because I thought it looked more readable, e.g., `a*x + b*y`. If I shouldn't have done this, please let me know and I'll push another commit.
Throughout: my personal recommendation is that new code uses `induction` rather than `induction'`

Throughout: mathlib style (due to mathport) leans towards including a space after ←.
```suggestion
  · simp [descPochhammer_succ_right, ih, ← Finset.prod_range_succ]
```

This seems to be a consequence of a more general result. That is, if `f` is decreasing and convex on `Set.Iic a` and `g` is increasing and convex on `Set.Ici a` and `f a = g a`, then `(Set.Iic a).piecewise f g` is convex.

I think proving the more general form would be easier, and then this result would be a one-line consequence (and could even be inlined in the place where it is needed).

> This seems to be a consequence of a more general result. That is, if `f` is decreasing and convex on `Set.Iic a` and `g` is increasing and convex on `Set.Ici a` and `f a = g a`, then `(Set.Iic a).piecewise f g` is convex.

I've added this (and similar) statement(s) to `Mathlib.Analysis.Convex.Piecewise`. 

Please let me know what you think.
I would probably use `n ≠ 0` here, as it's easier to supply a proof of that, but it's still equivalent.
Same here
Is there a more general lemma to extract here about piecewise on a complement? If that's already extracted, is it useful here?

`Set.piecewise_compl`? I tried this, it doesn't make that much progress.

`convexOn_univ_piecewise_Ici_of_monotoneOn_Ici_antitoneOn_Iic` is the only theorem to use this, I'll just put it there so it isn't a private lemma.

```suggestion
convex on the universal set. -/
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Analysis/SpecialFunctions): prove special case of Jensen's inequality for binomial coefficients
